Needless to say, such fear must be conquered. Enter Beowulf, a brave warrior that is not fazed with the possibility of death, mere monsters, or their overbearing moms. Long story short, he victoriously slews every one of them-even though his last encounter with the dragon cost him his life-coming out because singular hero who saved countless people. Hooray!

But some fear is not so conquerable. Driving a car of outside creatures or elements infiltrating a refuge is also found in William Golding's classic novel Lord of the Flies, in which a pack of British boys wash up on a deserted tropical island and begin to establish a semi-society so they can survive-sort of like the Dane and Geat tribes represented in Beowulf. The boys are common fearful of an imagined beast somewhere on the island, offering it severed pig heads to appease it, as if it were a monster within bed that could be satisfied by the stuffed teddy bear tossed under so that it won't gobble you up. Discuss childhood nightmares. Obviously, the childish fears are manifested in other events that bewilder the boys-such as being a lifeless parachuting man gliding toward the island.

However, the fear that plagues them isn't some Grendel-like creature which can be vanquished-it's something inside of the boys. Simon, the only real boy on the island who gets this fact, confirms his suspicions after the hallucinatory conversation with that severed pig head. Comparable to Edgar Allen Poe's The Raven in which a fairly one-sided talk with a stately bird causes the speaker to project his very own fears and grief until he descends into madness, Simon's discuss with the pig head also reflects the inner demons and monsters which can be at work within the human psyche. There won't be any dragons to be slain, no battles to get fought, and no opportunity for a Beowulf character to ride in and save the morning. The epic poem is targeted on the external and more manageable unknown, while Golding's novel takes that unknown and follows that fear within. Knowning that monster is something you are unable to fight off with a nightlight.
